bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, July 20, 1923

div1.p: Connor discusses his paper on yellow fever, including the use of scrubbed versus unscrubbed water barrels. He believes that the areas of North and Central America should be considered one unit because of modern transportation.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, July 20, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B-
Connor
PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
ESTADOS-UNIDOS-MEXICANOS
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE

----
COMISION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA.
----
PRIMERA ZONA

TAMPICO, TAMAULIPAS
Tampico Tamps.
July 20th 1923
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your memorandum and my MSS. arrived
here two days ago.

a. I am going to answer your questions
by numbers: Memo. page 2 par.5- I understand that
the aedes egypti are to be found in certain sections
of México city where the people are conserving their
water in receptacles in the home, in these places they
are fairly numerous. A case of yellow fever was
imported into Mexico City in 1921, the case was
still in the infective period but no further devolopments
were noted. Dr. Scannell had not received your letter up
to the time he left here.

b. From memorandum marked “For Dr. Connor
(To accompany MSS) page 2-8:P 2:” by ‘cycle period’
I was trying to express the observation that an area
or better still a region will more likly experience an
invasion of yellow fever after a free interval of many
years than if the comunity had been more recently
infected., for instance Pánuco reported its last case
of yellow fever previous to the epidemic of last year,
in 1903. The interval from 1903 to 1922 had seemingly been
free of the infection and therefore the city had a large
non-immune population (native). Now, it seems to me that i
if we had in mind the fact that from the time of the
last case of yellow fever (reported) 1903 to 1921 when
the first cases began to appear in Tampico that Pánuco, due
solely to the natural increase of its population, was
easily infected territory that work would have been
undertaken there. Yellow fever literature does not call
attention to this observation in a forceful way and I
am trying to express the thought.

c. page 3-16: P: 4:” True, many inmigrants come
to friends and many of these friends live in stegomyiae
free homes or all members of these home may be immunes.
In Guayaquil I personally followed the arrivals into that
city as the infection lessened and about 80% of new
arrivals sought and found lodging in the cheap boarding
houses. In bringing out such points would you not consider
that a service is being made in pointing out that phase
of a factor which if not stressed might be overlooked and
possibly lead to fatal results?

page 4- par.19: P: 6' We have some expe-
riements underway in Vuaghansarea to note the difference

breeding, first where the barrels have been
scrubbed and second in barrels not so treated.
It seems to me that if this mosquito does de-
posit her eggs above the water line as a regular
procedure that there should be a marked diffe-
rence in the containers reported having larvae
that have been scrubbed.

page 4- par. 20: P.: 6' My understanding
of the term ‘sporadic’ is a case of a disease
appearing at irregular intervals without any
known preceeding case of the same infection
in the community, in other words only infections,
the causative organism of which maintains its vitality
in the human host and may or may not give rise in
the ‘carrier’ to the symptom-complex attributed to
the particular organism or may not become active until
transferred to another person, the resulting illness
is spoken of as a ‘sporadic case’. The reason
that I emphasized the point that there can be no
'sporadic case of yellow fever in the MSS. is for
the sole purpose of bringing this fact home to
the Mexican physician, the majority of whom ‘love’
the term and use it whenever convienent. I feel that
our efforts here will be more successful if we
correct certain false impressions which the average
physician here entertains regarding yellow fever.,
than if we leave him to continue the old ideas.
One good result of our articles on yellow fever and
the campaign has been that more physicians/to-day in
Mexico are reading up than ever before and the reason
for this is that we have upset some of their old
theories and in their efforts to prove that their
ideas were right and ours wrong they have been obliged
to read and then they see the light, this explains
why I have stressed ‘ssporadic case’

Page 4- par.21-P-6' My thought here is
that the aedes egypti infested areas of North America
and Central America especially, must be considered as
one unit in the control of yellow fever due to the
excellent means of communications, land, water and air
The air traffic is not generally as yet but is beco-
ming more so each day and if we neglect to keep posted
on the conditions in Central Ameriaca it would be
possible to have a focus of infection there from
which the disease could pass later into Mexico and be
the nucleus of an epidemic, this assuming of course
that the present campaign had termitated.

Thanking you for your generous and frank
criticism of my MSS,
div1.closer: I am, very sincerely yours. M E Connor.
